title: 114_s1865
content:
The "Anna Westin Act of 2015" includes sections on short title, table of contents, findings, definitions, training and education, public service announcements, and more. The Congress finds that anorexia nervosa poses a high risk of death, with significant health consequences such as osteoporosis and cardiac issues. Approximately 14,500,000 people in the US suffer from eating disorders, with a high rate of comorbidity with other illnesses. Anorexia nervosa is characterized by self-starvation and weight loss. Anorexia nervosa is an eating disorder characterized by self-starvation, weight loss, and fear of gaining weight. It is associated with serious health consequences such as heart failure, kidney failure, and osteoporosis. Bulimia nervosa has a lifetime prevalence between 0.9-1.5% among women and 0.1-0.5% among men, with health risks like cardiac issues and dental problems. Binge eating disorder involves frequent episodes of uncontrolled overeating, affecting 3.5% of women and 2.0% of men in the US. Eating disorders, such as anorexia nervosa, bulimia nervosa, and binge eating disorder, affect a significant percentage of the population. Binge eating is linked to various health issues like obesity, high blood pressure, and increased cancer risks. Rates of unhealthy dieting behaviors are prevalent among young women. While more common in women, eating disorders also occur in men, with similar rates of binge eating disorder between genders. The use of very thin models in advertising has been connected to eating disorder development. Academic evidence shows a link between using very thin models in advertising and consumer attitudes towards brands. Eating disorders affect all demographics in the US and are associated with psychological issues like depression and substance abuse. Hospitalizations for eating disorders in children under 12 increased by 119% between 1999 and 2006. The Act defines "eating disorder" to include various conditions like anorexia nervosa and bulimia nervosa. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Health and Human Services. The Secretary, in consultation with the Secretary of Education, will update and reinstate the BodyWise Handbook with information on eating disorders for males and females. This information will be incorporated into the BodyWorks obesity prevention program curriculum and training modules. The updated resources will be made publicly available. The BodyWise Handbook and related resources, along with the BodyWorks obesity prevention program, will be updated and made publicly available for educating universities and nonprofit entities on eating disorders. SEC. 6. EDUCATION AND TRAINING FOR HEALTH PROFESSIONALS. The Secretary will award grants to integrate training on eating disorders into existing curricula for healthcare professionals. This includes early intervention, levels of treatment, referral procedures, prevention strategies, and treatment methods. Entities seeking grants must submit an application detailing their plan for fund usage and training evaluation. Entities receiving grants under this section must use the funds to develop evidence-based training programs on identifying, intervening, and treating eating disorders. Training may include Internet-based courses and conferences. The grants aim to develop evidence-based training programs on identifying, intervening, and treating eating disorders. This includes conducting comprehensive assessments of health risk factors and treatment plans, as well as evaluating the effectiveness of the training provided. SEC. 7. EDUCATION AND TRAINING FOR SCHOOL AND HIGHER EDUCATION PROFESSIONALS. The Secretary shall award grants to eligible entities for educational seminars on early identification, intervention, and prevention of eating disorders, and to provide resources to individuals affected by eating disorders. Eligible entities must conduct seminars considering materials from the BodyWise eating disorder initiative and relevant research. Eligible entities include states, territories, tribes, and organizations. The curr_chunk states that grants can be awarded to entities such as the District of Columbia, Indian tribes, educational institutions, including higher education institutions. The Director of the National Institute of Mental Health will conduct public service announcements to educate the public on eating disorders, including types, seriousness, prevention, and effects of media on self-esteem. Collaboration with centers of excellence and national nonprofit resources is required. SEC. 9. CLARIFYING APPLICATION OF EXISTING PARITY LAW. (a) PHSA.--Section 2726 of the Public Health Service Act (42 U.S.C. 300gg-26) is amended to include provisions regarding the treatment of permanent exclusions under mental health and substance use disorder benefits in group health plans or health insurance coverage. Additionally, mental health and substance use disorder benefits now include residential treatment. 
(b) ERISA.--Section 712 of the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 (29 U.S.C. 1185a) is amended to address similar issues related to mental health and substance use disorder benefits. The Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 and the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 are amended to address the treatment of permanent exclusions under mental health and substance use disorder benefits in group health plans or health insurance coverage. This includes provisions for residential treatment. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to address permanent exclusions under mental health and substance use disorder benefits in group health plans. This includes provisions for residential treatment. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to address mental health and addiction services in group health plans. No additional funds are authorized for this Act or its amendments; existing funds will be used instead.
